III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that youth fight and staff do nothing. It is also alleged
that essentials are not provided for youth and youth do not attend
school regularly.
Investigation Staff 1, the agency case manager for the program, was
notified of the allegation and interviewed by telephone on
May 31, 2024 and June 18, 2024. Staff 1 reported the program is
staffed 16 hours per day. Staff 1 was asked about fights among
Independent Living (IL) youth occurring at the agency and what is
the procedure for staff intervention. Staff 1 reported fights among
IL youth are an infrequent occurrence but when they occur the
procedure is for staff to call the police. Staff 1 reported staff do not
conduct restraints and they use de-escalation techniques. Staff 1
denied that when a fight does occur that staff do nothing. Staff 1
reported that IL youth get into arguments frequently but reiterated
that physical fights are an infrequent occurrence.
Staff 1 was asked if IL youth have basic living essentials. Staff 1
reported that IL youth receive $385 dollars every two weeks and
they also have food cards to purchase food. Staff 1 denied that
any of the IL youth are without essential living items such as food,
hygiene items, and medications if needed.
Staff 1 was asked if IL youth attend school. Staff 1 reported the IL
youth attend the Flex Alternative School on Mondays and
Wednesdays. Staff 1 reported the agency transports youth to and
from school. Staff 1 reported youth at times elect not to go to
2

school on any particular day and the agency staff cannot force
them to attend school.
The Complainant was contacted by telephone on June 5,
2024, and July 24, 2024. The Complainant reported she is
concerned that agency staff are not ensuring IL youth attend
school and the youth have too much independence. The
Complainant reported IL Youth A, B, C, and D have informed her
that they do not have essentials, and when fights occur, staff do
nothing.
Youth A was interviewed via video on June 18, 2024. Youth A
reported she entered the program in March 2024. Youth A
reported that things are going well for her at the program. Youth A
reported she feels safe at the program. Youth A was asked if she
had ever witnessed a fight at the program. Youth A reported she
had not seen any fights among the IL youth, only arguments.
Youth A was asked what the staff are supposed to do if there is a
fight and she replied they are supposed to call the police. Youth A
reported staff try to deescalate arguments among youth when they
occur.
Youth A reported she attends the alternative school on Mondays
and Wednesdays, and she attends regularly. Youth A reported
staff provide transportation to and from school.
Youth A was asked about basic living essentials. Youth A reported
she receives $385 every two weeks, and she has a Bridge Card,
which is used to purchase food. Youth A reported staff had helped
her obtain the card. Youth A reported she has enough money for
food and hygiene products. Youth A reported she plans to attend
Western Michigan University.
Youth B was interviewed via video on June 18, 2024. Youth B
reported she has been in the program since February 2024. Youth
B reported she witnessed one fight and staff called the police.
Youth B reported staff try to deescalate youth who are upset.
Youth B reported she feels safe in the program.
Youth B reported she attends school at the Flex Alternative High
School on Mondays and Wednesdays. Youth B reported the
agency provides transportation to and from school.
Youth B reported she receives $385 every two weeks and has
food assistance via a Bridge Card. Youth B reported she has
enough money to provide for food and hygiene products.
3

Youth C was interviewed by video on June 18, 2024. Youth C
reported she has seen two fights while in the program. Youth C
reported staff call the police when this happens. Youth C reported
staff try to deescalate situations as they occur. Youth C reported
she feels safe at the program.
Youth C reported she attends the Flex Alternative High School on
Mondays and Wednesdays but that she does not go as often as
she should. Youth C reported staff encourage school attendance
but reiterated that she does not always attend. Youth C reported
the agency provides transportation to and from school.
Youth C reported she receives $385 dollars every two weeks and
also received food assistance via Bridge Card. Youth C reported
she has enough money to provide for herself. Youth C reported
she plans to attend college at Central Michigan University.
Youth D declined to be interviewed.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on June 18, 2024. Staff 2
is a “Youth Recovery Worker” and works directly with youth on the
“floor” on a day to day basis. Staff 2 reported she began
employment in July 2023. Staff 2 reported she has not witnessed
any fights between IL youth. Staff 2 reported staff try to deescalate
youth when they become upset and verbally threatening. Staff 2
denied that staff do nothing when youth become upset or
threatening.
Staff 2 reported the agency provides transportation for IL youth to
and from the alternative school. Staff 2 reported some youth often
refuse to go to school and staff cannot make them go.
Staff 2 reported IL youth receive checks every two weeks as well
as food assistance. Staff 2 reported that IL youth’s basic living
needs are met.
The Program Manager was interviewed on July 25, 2024, via
telephone. Then Program Manager reported that law
enforcement is called when an IL youth becomes verbally
threatening towards staff and invades the personal space of staff.
The Program Manager reported that physical altercations among
youth is infrequent and most of the time it is a youth threatening a
staff. The Program Manager reported in either case, the police are
called. The Program Manager reported staff are trained to
deescalate youth when they are upset and threatening.
4

The Program Manager reported youth have adequate financial
resources and their daily living needs are met.
The Program Manager reported IL youth attend school but often
elect not to attend on any given day. The Program Manager
reported staff cannot make youth attend school. The Program
Manager was asked what happens if an IL youth quits attending
school. The Program Manager reported attending school is a
requirement of eligibility for participation in the program and if a
youth quits attending, a Family Team Meeting is held with the
DHHS Monitor, the agency case manager, Director, and others to
assist the youth in returning to attending school.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEW:
• The files of Youth A, B, and C were reviewed. The review
did not add anything to the investigation.
Analysis Youth A reported she has not seen a fight while placed in the
program. Youth A added staff are required to call the police if a
fight occurs. Youth B and C reported they have seen fights occur
and staff called the police.
Youth A, B, and C reported they receive bi-weekly checks as part
of the IL program and in addition they have food assistance. Youth
A, B, and C reported they adequate living essentials such as food,
hygiene and medications.
Youth A, B, and C reported they attend an alternative school and
the agency provides transportation.
Staff 1 reported that fights among IL are infrequent, and staff call
the police when they occur. Staff 1 reported youth receive $385
every two weeks and also have food assistance. Staff 1 reported
that youths daily living essentials are being met. Staff 1 reported
that youth attend school and are provided transportation. Staff 1
reported at times youth elect not to go to school.
Staff 2 reported she had not witnessed any fights among IL youth
and staff are required to call the police should a fight occur. Staff 2
reiterated what Staff 1, and Youth A, B, and C had reported
regarding youth having basic living essentials and attending
school.
The Program Manager reported that fights among IL youth are
infrequent, and staff are required to call the police when this
5

occurs. The Program Manager reported youth receive adequate
financial resources and their daily needs are met. The Program
Manager reported IL youth attend school and often elect not to go.
The Program Manager reported attending school is a requirement
for attending the program and if non-attendance becomes a
repetitive problem, an FTM is held to assist the youth in attending
school and fulfilling the school requirement.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
